body_html:
(From API-review)

If we add this function, users could do:

variables = estimator. get_variable_value(list_of_vars)

Without this function, users would have to do:

variables = {n: estimator.get_variable_value(n) for n in list_of_vars}

Is that right?
If so, we'd prefer to not add an API function for that.

However, note that the current implementation will open (and close) the checkpoint file once per variable. If instead we try to be more efficient by opening the checkpoint file once and reading all the variables, then a new API would be reasonable since it would be more performant than what can be achieved with a simple composition of the existing API.

However, note that the current implementation will open (and close) the checkpoint file once per variable. If instead we try to be more efficient by opening the checkpoint file once and reading all the variables, then a new API would be reasonable since it would be more performant than what can be achieved with a simple composition of the existing API.
body:
(From API-review)

If we add this function, users could do:

```python
variables = estimator. get_variable_value(list_of_vars)
```

Without this function, users would have to do:

```python
variables = {n: estimator.get_variable_value(n) for n in list_of_vars}
```

Is that right?
If so, we'd prefer to not add an API function for that.

However, note that the current implementation will open (and close) the checkpoint file once per variable. If instead we try to be more efficient by opening the checkpoint file once and reading all the variables, then a new API would be reasonable since it would be more performant than what can be achieved with a simple composition of the existing API.
